newsitem.title: USA: USTR reviews Philippines' pork dispute.
newsitem.headline: USTR reviews Philippines' pork dispute.

text.p: The U.S. Trade Representative's office said Thursday it would review the Philippines' participation in a special U.S. trade program because of a complaint by U.S. meat producers that the Philippines blocked fair market access for U.S. pork exports.

A petition filed by the Meat Industry Trade Policy Council on behalf of several groups, including the National Pork Producers Council, claimed that the Philippines has "subverted" market access by government allocation procedures.
Last year, 85 percent of the Philippines' tariff rate quota was allocated to domestic hog producers, the complaint said.

"We have already initiated consultations with the Philippines government at the World Trade Organization about this particular situation," U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said in a statement. "While we are pursuing the matter in the WTO, we will consider the petitioners' concerns on a parallel track under our Generalized System of Preferences statute."

The generalized system of proferences grants duty-free treatment to specific products imported from more than 140 developing countries. The program is designed to encourage beneficiaries to reduce trade barriers. ((Washington commodities desk, 202 898 8467))
